results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 161]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is a wonderful snapshot of Jess and Ron Gadsden at the start of their life together, in Melbourne, with other members of the family and with their first child. There are some travel scenes and 1940s fashion.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 looking out across the red rooftop of a house over a waterway and some chimney smoke
00:00:23:00 first introduction to a young Jess Gadsden as she walks up an outside stair near alongside a house
00:00:31:00 Jess Gadsden walking in the gardens of a large country hotel
00:00:48:00 Ron Gadsden wearing 1940s style wide suit pants and jacket standing by a 1940s style car
00:00:55:00 a punt ferrying cars across a river followed by a weir across a broad river
00:01:14:00 a crowd watching rowing races on the Yarra River in Melbourne
00:01:25:00 several ladies hats of the period on show as the wearers view the races
00:01:30:00 Jess Gadsden in matching green hat and coat looking at flowers in a park
00:01:42:00 Ron Gadsden wandering in the Treasury Gardens near St Patrick’s Cathedral in Melbourne, enjoying a cigarette
00:02:15:00 brown trams on a wide city street
00:02:30:00 Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:02:45:00 Jess Gadsden and companions dressed in what was called ‘Sunday best’ outfits, 1940s style - complete with hats, gloves and handbags, descending down church steps
00:03:45:00 Ron Gadsden and baby on a blanket
00:04:08:00 Jess Gadsden in wonderful sunglasses and baby with an older women overlooking a beautiful view below
00:04:24:00 a wide sandy beach followed by a holiday resort
00:05:15:00 looking out over the Blue Mountains including the Three Sisters rock formation
00:06:20:00 a gathering of Gadsdens in a park followed by views of autumn trees
00:07:06:00 a wonderful scene of what appears to be the first of Ron’s and Jess’s children with his grandmothers (one of them with a cigarette) dressed in very smart 1940s suits, hats and bag sitting in front of Ron, a building with a double verandah and a beautiful car of the era
00:07:35:00 a long pan shot from a high vantage point above the sea, beach and houses below ending at a look-out point where we see the Gadsden family
00:08:19:00 at ‘old Parliament House’ (as it is now known) in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 152]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This short film shows small yachts sailing on Port Phillip Bay near Frankston, Victoria in 1969. Teams of 3 are shown sailing small wooden yachts and possibly racing. Some beach scenes are included.

This film was originally made using 16mm film. Much of the footage of the sailing is overexposed and slightly out of focus.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 147]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film contains scenes of camping near the beach and a rail journey to Perth, in Western Australia. The trip includes a stop at ‘Rawlinna’, an Aboriginal community in Western Australia. Scenes at Rawlinna, give an indication of the relationship in society of Australian Aboriginal peoples and non-indigenous Australian people at the time.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 1940s cars travel across sand on a beach
00:00:08:00 a tea ‘billy’ on a camp fire
00:00:31:00 a large 1940s style canvas tent
00:00:55:00 overlooking the sea from clifftops
00:01:30:00 members of the Rawlinna Station Indigenous community stand for the camera and demonstrate boomerang throwing
00:02:36:00 travellers walk toward the camera
00:03:01:00 chasing a goat
00:03:04:00 playing a game of ‘two-up’
00:03:21:00 members of the Rawlinna Station Indigenous community
00:03:30:00 wandering along a constructed stone wall at a river or waterway

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 145]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows yachts sailing around a spot in (most probably) Port Phillip Bay and a school swimming competition.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:04:19:00 yachts racing
00:04:39:00 boats and yachts berthed on the sand
00:04:40:00 single person yachts on the water
00:03:03:00 indoor pool and swimmers
00:03:15:00 students assembling by the pool in readiness for swimming
00:03:18:00 swimmers in competition
00:03:58:00 relay in the pool

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 166]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This is a particularly lovely colour film comprising scenes from Ron and Jess Gadsden’s early life when their children were small, in 1952. They are enjoying life at home (Lansell Rd, Toorak in Melbourne), sitting in the sun with the children, on the beach at Frankston on the Mornington Peninsula and a birthday for one of the girls back at Lansell Rd.

The second half of the film shows school sports at the Geelong Grammar Toorak Campus, ‘Glamorgan’, which Ron films through a round frame.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 Jess Gadsden teaches one of her children to swim in shallows at Frankston beach
00:01:59:00 view of Frankston bay with cliff top houses in the background
00:02:20:00 filmmaker Ron playing in water with his children
00:03:12:00 Jess preparing lunch on a small plate sitting on the beach
00:04:14:00 birthday party at Jess and Ron Gadsden’s home, with family and pony rides
00:06:42:00 sports day for primary school children with onlooking parents and teachers guiding the proceedings

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 134]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This short film shows skiing at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales, Australia.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:11:00 a skier falls over in spectacular style
00:02:00:00 view over one of the resort valleys, with heavy snow cover

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 133]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is in two parts. The first shows downhill skiing at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. The second, a sports day at ‘Glamorgan’ kindergarten, now the Melbourne ‘prep’ campus of Geelong Grammar.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00 skiing downhill past camera
00:01:22 skier walking cross country, building in background
00:01:29 child skiing
00:01:43 close up footage of ski lodge verandah
00:01:50 school boys lining up
00:02:03 running and wheelbarrow races on grass
00:02:54 high jump over bar on wooden blocks
00:03:13 closeup female teacher
00:03:17 bean bag race
00:03:48 running race with midway stop to put on painting smock
00:04:21 women and school girls (in hats) watch sports – hats and sunglasses
00:04:29 timekeepers desk

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 84]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

This film shows the ‘J. Gadsden Pty. Ltd.’ factory in North Coburg (now a heritage listed location) from early construction through to completion and operational. We see the production line during the manufacture of Coralite British Kerosene packaging and other unidentified products.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 53]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

Members of the Gadsden family on a skiing holiday at Falls Creek in Victoria in 1974. The family and their guests were all keen skiers and in this and other films Ron shows the atmosphere of their skiing holidays – the snow falling on buildings and slopes, the banks of snow, the ski village and activity.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 snow falling on a house roof, snowfields and trees
00:00:36:00 members of the Gadsden circle skiing downhill and performing jumps in the air
00:01:52:00 a ‘ski hoist’
00:02:16:00 Jess Gadsden, wearing one of her headscarves, prepares to ski
00:02:21:00 looking down at the ski resort from a higher vantage point
00:03:30:00 views around the slopes
00:05:45:00 the younger Gadsdens ski down a slope in short skis, ending with a flourish
00:06:54:00 more skiing around the slopes
00:07:20:00 using the ‘ski hoist’
00:09:21:00 skiers coming down the slope in succession
00:10:10:00 some falls in the snow followed by some tricks on skis.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the 1977 National Titles skiing competition at Thredbo in NSW.

Members of the Gadsden family were keen skiers and most of this film is taken up with downhill skiing competitions in which the they would take part. The camera captures the speed and difficulty of the downwards skiing in the competition and indecently shows contemporary snowfield fashions.

There are also scenes of the ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’ and surrounds including a steaming pool, chalets and mountains in the background, as well as some of the Gadsdens and their cars.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:17:00:00 sign ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’
